title: FirstGroup squeezes out activist via a share sale
text:
Transport operator FirstGroup has launched a tender offer that will rid itself of Coast Capital Management, the activist fund that had successfully lobbied to oust chief executive Matthew Gregory.

FirstGroup set out plans to return up to £500m to shareholders via a tender at 105p a share, a  9.2 per cent premium to Tuesday's closing price of 96.15p. It said that Coast, a 12.8 per cent shareholder, had given an irrevocable undertaking to support the resolutions and tender its full holdings.

New York-based Coast waged a long campaign against FirstGroup's board and management, including a push to separate its US and UK operations. Most recently it accused management of bungling the $3.1bn sale of its US bus business, saying the disposal to Swedish private equity group EQT significantly undervalued the business and “stinks to the heavens”.

Briefly

Rishi Sunak, chancellor of the exchequer, will claim that he has successfully steered the economy through the Covid-19 crisis today, unveiling a Budget that will combine a new commitment to fiscal discipline with extra spending on essential public services and measures to tackle the cost-of-living crisis.

Wickes, the home improvement retailer, said it remained on track to hit full-year targets. Sales last quarter moderated by 1.6 per cent against the pandemic-inflated 2020 result but were up 16.3 per cent versus the same period in 2019, Wickes said in a trading update.

Bloomsbury Publishing raised its interim dividend after delivering a more than trebling of half-year earnings. The book publisher reported a half year pre-tax profit of £11.1m, from £3m the year before, on revenue up 29 per cent to £100.7m. Bloomsbury noted continued supply chain problems but reiterated guidance for its financial year ending February 2022, saying that its non-consumer titles would provide insulation from what was likely to be a competitive Christmas.

Package holiday company On The Beach said it was still unable to provide any financial guidance for the 2022 financial year ending September, in spite of a recent pick-up in bookings. The company's year-end trading update gave no financial metrics other than reporting cash excluding customer deposits in excess of £55m and a £75m undrawn credit facility.

Aveva, the industrial software maker, said underlying organic revenue grew 9 per cent in the six months to September. All business lines improved total fees with a “particularly strong” contribution from its recently acquired OSIsoft business, the company said in a half-year trading update.

Home emergency assistance service HomeServe said it had agreed to buy CET Structures, a UK peer, for £53m.

Beyond the Square Mile

Alphabet, Google's parent company, and Microsoft both posted strong revenue growth in the third quarter, while Twitter swung to a loss, as the three US tech companies released results.

Banco Santander reported a €2.2bn of profit for the third quarter, 24 per cent ahead of the same period last year, as the Spanish lender benefited from its relative strength in the US and UK markets as well as from digitalisation.

Deutsche Bank's third quarter net profit attributable to shareholders rose by 7 per cent to €194m, beating analyst expectations of €135m. The boom in mergers and acquisitions and a sharp year-on-year reduction in provisions for credit losses helped offset a drop in trading revenues.

Gazprom has proposed that the former Soviet republic adjust its free trade deal with the European Union and delay energy market reforms agreed with Brussels in exchange for cheaper gas for the country.

Spain's state-owned train company Renfe is looking at operating a new high-speed rail link between London and Paris, a move that would place it in direct competition with Eurostar.

EQT is exploring a potential acquisition of Temenos, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg. The Stockholm-based buyout group is in the early stages of considering a bid for the $9.9bn-valued Swiss banking software specialist, it reported.

Essential comment before you go

Martin Wolf issues a call for urgent action ahead of the COP26 climate summit. “Pledges of ‘net zero' thirty years from now are too easy. It is necessary to cut emissions by close to 40 per cent by 2030, instead. The curve of emissions must be bent downwards now.”
